name: noaa_sea-level-trends
title: Sea Level Trends
description:
U.S. Linear Relative Mean Sea Level (MSL) trends and 95% Confidence Intervals (CI) in mm/year and in ft/century.

> Data on Sea Level trends from the Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS).

`In-The-News`:
* Miami New Times: [Study: Miami's Causeways Highly Vulnerable to Sea-Level Rise](http://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/study-miamis-causeways-highly-vulnerable-to-sea-level-rise-8991914)
* San Francisco Chronicle: [King tides expected to have more impact as sea levels rise](http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/place/article/King-tides-expected-to-have-more-impact-as-sea-10794305.php)
* Scientific American: [The Greater New York City Region Must Plan for "Permanent Flooding"](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-greater-new-york-city-region-must-plan-for-permanent-flooding/)
* Fox News: [West Antarctic ice sheet could collapse, causing significant sea level rise, experts warn](http://www.foxnews.com/science/2016/03/31/west-antarctic-ice-sheet-could-collapse-causing-significant-sea-level-rise-experts-warn.html)
* Vice News: [It's Been 30 Centuries Since Sea Levels Were Rising This Quickly](https://news.vice.com/article/its-been-30-centuries-since-sea-levels-were-rising-this-quickly)

![Sea Level Trends.png](https://data.world/api/noaa/dataset/sea-level-trends/file/raw/Sea%20Level%20Trends.png)
_Image from https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/sltrends.html_

## Notes
* Changes in Mean Sea Level (MSL), either a sea level rise or sea level fall, have been computed at 142 long-term water level stations using a minimum span of 30 years of observations at each location.
* The measurements have been averaged by month to remove the effect of higher frequency phenomena.

## About CO-OPS    
The Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS) and its predecessors have gathered oceanographic data along our nation's coasts for over 200 years to protect life, property, and the environment. Serving both the public and other government agencies, CO-OPS is the authoritative source for accurate, reliable, and timely water-level and current measurements that support safe and efficient maritime commerce, sound coastal management, and recreation. The combined efforts, knowledge, and experience of CO-OPS's technicians, scientists, and engineers working to carry out a central mission has led to the development of a reliable center of expertise for coastal physical oceanography.

_Source: [noaa.gov](https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/mslUSTrendsTable.htm)_
